pli-tv-kd22:1.1.2: Most of these practices are obscure. They are explained further down in the text.
pli-tv-kd22:1.7.5: See the Critical Pali Dictionary, sub-point 3g, for this use of kata.
pli-tv-kd22:1.10.13: Sp-ṭ.1.0: Siṅgena loṇaṁ pariharitvā pariharitvā aloṇakapiṇḍapātena saddhiṁ bhuñjituṁ kappati, na sannidhiṁ karotīti adhippāyo, “Carrying salt in horn here and there, is it allowable to eat it together with unsalted almsfood? The meaning is one should not store it.”
pli-tv-kd22:2.3.34: Sp-ṭ.3.4.454: Garunissayaṁ gaṇhāmāti kiñcāpi mayaṁ mahallakā, etaṁ pana theraṁ garuṁ katvā vasissāmāti adhippāyo, “Garunissayaṁ gaṇhāma: although I am a senior monk, I will dwell respecting this senior monk.” | Vmv.4.454 adds: Garunissayaṁ gaṇhāmāti nissayamuttāpi mayaṁ ekaṁ sambhāvanīyagaruṁ nissayabhūtaṁ gahetvāva vasissāmāti adhippāyo, “Garunissayaṁ gaṇhāma: even though I no longer need support, I will live supported by one who is to be respected.”
pli-tv-kd22:2.4.4: Vmv.4.455 explains mūlādāyakā as follows: Mūlādāyakāti paṭhamaṁ dasavatthūnaṁ dāyakā, “Mūlādāyakā means those who first gave the ten practices.”
pli-tv-kd22:2.5.5: Sp.4.455: Kullakavihārenāti uttānavihārena, “Kullakavihāra means a straightforward meditation.” This, however, seems like a put-down, which does not fit the context well. It seems more likely to me that kullaka is instead related to Sanskrit kulya, “of a good/noble family”.
pli-tv-kd22:2.8.20: Literally, “This is the first voting ticket that I place.”
pli-tv-kd22:2.8.23: Literally, “When two finger-breadths of shade have passed, is it allowable to eat at the wrong time.” I interpret this to mean within two finger-breadths of midday.
pli-tv-kd22:2.8.50: Uposathasaṁyutta is identified at Sp-ṭ.3.4.457 as the Uposathakkhandhaka, “The Chapter on the Observance Day”. But perhaps it is best regarded as a forerunner to the Uposathakkhandhaka.
pli-tv-kd22:2.8.109: Sp.4.457: Chedanakasikkhāpade vuttapācittiyaṁ āpajjatīti attho, “The meaning is he commits the said offense entailing confession in the training rule on cutting.”
